summary: This document is a Request for Quotation (RFQ) issued by Great Lakes Chemical Processing (GLCP) in Hamilton, Ontario, seeking qualified NDE contractors to perform ultrasonic thickness (UT) survey services on piping systems within their Amine Treating Unit (ATU-100). The scope covers 150 Condition Monitoring Locations (CMLs) across 18 piping lines over an estimated 4 field days scheduled for November 4-7, 2024. The work is part of GLCP's mechanical integrity program per API 570 requirements. Piping includes carbon steel (A106 Gr.B) and 316SS lines ranging from 2" to 8" in services including rich/lean amine, sour gas, treated gas, reflux, and cooling water. Contractors must provide UT Level II certified personnel (ASNT SNT-TC-1A), digital thickness gauges with 0.001" resolution, and compare results against 2019 baseline survey data to calculate corrosion rates. Deliverables include a comprehensive inspection report, raw data files, photographs, and corrosion rate calculations. The proposal deadline is October 22, 2024, with a minimum $2M general liability insurance requirement.

This document (GLCP-NDT-001, Revision 3, effective January 15, 2024) establishes site-specific Non-Destructive Examination (NDE) requirements for the Great Lakes Chemical Processing Hamilton Plant. It covers all NDE activities including UT, MT, PT, VT, and RT performed on pressure-containing equipment and piping systems. The document references key industry codes including API 570, API 510, ASME B31.3, and ASNT SNT-TC-1A. It specifies minimum Level II certification for all NDE personnel with varying experience requirements, and mandates a 4-hour site-specific safety orientation. Equipment requirements include UT gauge specifications, NIST-traceable calibration with 12-month intervals, and daily verification within ±0.002 inch tolerance. UT measurement procedures require minimum four readings per CML location at 90° spacing, with the minimum reading recorded as official. Alert thresholds classify findings as Critical (below t-min requiring immediate stop-work notification), Alert (below 110% t-min), Monitor (corrosion rate above 10 mpy), or Acceptable. Safety requirements include General Work Permits, personal H2S monitors in the Amine Treating Unit with alarms at 10/15 ppm, and comprehensive PPE including FR clothing. The GLCP Inspection Coordinator is Jennifer Walsh.

This document is a Request for Quotation (RFQ) from Great Lakes Chemical Processing (GLCP) in Hamilton, Ontario, seeking qualified NDE contractors to perform ultrasonic thickness (UT) survey services on piping systems within their Amine Treating Unit (ATU-100). The scope includes 150 Condition Monitoring Locations (CMLs) across 18 piping lines, with field work estimated at 4 days scheduled for November 4-7, 2024. The work must comply with API 570 piping inspection code requirements and other applicable standards including API 574, ASME B31.3, and ASME Section V. Contractors must provide UT Level II certified personnel with minimum 5 years refinery/petrochemical experience. Deliverables include thickness measurements, corrosion rate calculations comparing to 2019 baseline data, identification of readings below minimum thickness (t-min), photographs, and a comprehensive inspection report. The RFQ specifies equipment requirements including digital instruments with 0.001" resolution and data logging capability. Proposals are due October 22, 2024, with anticipated contract award on October 25, 2024. The piping systems include rich amine, lean amine, sour gas, cooling water, and reflux services in various sizes from 2" to 8".

This document (GLCP-NDT-001, Revision 3) establishes site-specific Non-Destructive Examination (NDE) requirements for the Great Lakes Chemical Processing Hamilton Plant. It covers NDE activities including ultrasonic thickness measurement (UT), magnetic particle testing (MT), liquid penetrant testing (PT), visual inspection (VT), and radiographic testing (RT) on pressure-containing equipment and piping systems. The specification details personnel qualification requirements per ASNT SNT-TC-1A, with minimum Level II certification and varying experience requirements for different inspection activities. Equipment requirements specify digital UT gauges with data logging capability and NIST-traceable calibration. UT measurement procedures require minimum four readings per CML location with the minimum value recorded. Alert thresholds define CRITICAL (below t-min requiring immediate stop-work and notification), Alert (below 110% t-min), and Monitor (corrosion rate exceeding 10 mpy) conditions. Documentation must include electronic data logging, photographs of CML locations and critical findings, and comprehensive reports with trending analysis. Safety requirements mandate work permits, H2S monitoring in the Amine Treating Unit, and specific PPE including FR clothing. The document was last revised January 2024 by J. Walsh.

This document is a Request for Quotation (RFQ) issued by Great Lakes Chemical Processing (GLCP) for ultrasonic thickness (UT) survey services on piping systems in the Amine Treating Unit (ATU-100) at their Hamilton Plant. It outlines requirements for NDE contractors, specifying the scope of work such as UT measurements, data logging, photographing CMLs, comparing current and historic data, corrosion rate calculations, and comprehensive reporting. The survey covers 18 piping lines and 150 CMLs, with work scheduled for November 2024. Contractors must meet technical qualifications (API 570, API 574, ASME standards), provide calibrated, digital UT equipment, and ensure personnel qualifications (UT Level II minimum). Deliverables include draft/final inspection reports, raw data, photos, calibration and certification documentation, and daily field reports. Proposals must demonstrate relevant experience, provide team certifications, equipment and safety compliance details, pricing, insurance, and references. Attachments include piping line/CML summaries, prior survey data, isometric drawings, and site-specific requirements.

This document, titled 'Site-Specific NDE Requirements' for the Great Lakes Chemical Processing Hamilton Plant, outlines mandatory protocols for Non-Destructive Examination (NDE) activities conducted at the site. It applies to ultrasonic thickness measurement (UT), magnetic particle testing (MT), liquid penetrant testing (PT), visual (VT), and radiographic testing (RT) on pressure systems. All NDE personnel must be qualified per ASNT SNT-TC-1A or CP-189, with specified experience requirements for each task. Equipment, especially UT gauges, must meet strict calibration and operational criteria, with documented daily verification. Measurement procedures prescribe surface preparation, couplant selection, and reading protocols, while minimum thicknesses (t-min) are set against industry codes. Findings are categorized by severity, with immediate action required for readings below t-min. Reports must be detailed, including digital data and photographic evidence. Additional requirements include mandatory safety orientation, PPE, permit compliance, and H2S monitoring for hazardous areas. The document also details photographic documentation criteria and has a revision history listing major updates, ensuring comprehensive, standardized NDE practices at the facility.

The document is a Request for Quotation (RFQ) issued by Great Lakes Chemical Processing for ultrasonic thickness survey services on their Amine Treating Unit (ATU-100) at the Hamilton Plant. The RFQ outlines the scope of work which includes conducting ultrasonic measurements at designated CMLs, recording thickness readings, photographing CML locations, comparing current and historical data, and calculating corrosion rates. The work must adhere to specified codes such as API 570 and ASME B31.3. The contractor is required to provide personnel qualified to ASNT SNT-TC-1A standards, with daily field calibration and comprehensive safety compliance. Deliverables include inspection reports, raw data files, and calibration certificates. The proposal must include company qualifications, a detailed work plan, and lump sum pricing. Key dates are provided for the proposal timeline, with field work scheduled for November 2024. Attachments include piping line lists, CML summaries, and site-specific requirements.

The document 'Site-Specific NDE Requirements' for the Great Lakes Chemical Processing Hamilton Plant outlines procedures and standards for Non-Destructive Examination (NDE) activities. It covers the applicability of ultrasonic, magnetic particle, liquid penetrant, visual, and radiographic testing on pressure-containing equipment. Personnel engaged in these activities must be qualified according to ASNT standards and undergo site-specific training. Equipment, particularly ultrasonic gauges, has strict calibration and operational requirements, ensuring measurement accuracy. The document details procedures for surface preparation, couplant usage, and measurement techniques, specifying actions for thickness readings below minimum thresholds. Critical findings necessitate immediate cessation of work and notification to the inspection coordinator. Data recording and photographic documentation are crucial, with all findings to be comprehensively reported. Safety requirements include obtaining work permits and using personal protective equipment, especially in high-risk areas. The document concludes with a revision history detailing updates since its initial issue.

The document is a Request for Quotation (RFQ) from Great Lakes Chemical Processing (GLCP) for ultrasonic thickness survey services on piping systems within the Amine Treating Unit (ATU-100) at their Hamilton Plant. The RFQ specifies the scope of work, requiring the contractor to perform ultrasonic thickness measurements at designated Condition Monitoring Locations (CMLs) and to record and analyze data compared to historical readings. It highlights compliance with various industry standards including API 570 and ASME B31.3. Key deliverables include a comprehensive inspection report, raw data, and required certifications. The schedule outlines key dates from RFQ issuance to final report submission, and safety requirements mandate adherence to specific GLCP protocols. Proposal requirements specify qualifications, work plans, pricing details, and insurance proof. Overall, the document outlines a structured approach to ensure the integrity and safety of the piping systems through detailed inspection processes.

The document outlines site-specific Non-Destructive Examination (NDE) requirements for Great Lakes Chemical Processing's Hamilton Plant, effective January 15, 2024. It details the qualification standards for NDE personnel, requiring certifications in accordance with ASNT SNT-TC-1A or CP-189 with specific experience levels for different examination techniques. Equipment requirements include precise specifications for ultrasonic thickness gauges, calibration protocols, and daily verification practices. Procedures for ultrasonic thickness measurement encompass surface preparation, couplant usage, and measurement techniques, along with acceptance criteria for thickness readings. Critical thresholds mandate immediate reporting protocols for low readings. Safety measures highlight the necessity of work permits and H2S monitoring. Documentation requirements emphasize electronic data recording, photographic evidence of findings, and structured reporting formats. The document serves as a comprehensive guide to ensuring both safety and quality in NDE activities at the facility.
